sections.Confirmation:
This course syllabus was confirmed by The IT Faculty Board on 2011-05-20 and was
last revised on 2014-11-13 by Department of Computer Science and Engineering to be
valid from 2015-08-30, autumn semester of 2015.
sections.Position in the educational system:
The course can be part of the following programmes: 1) Computer Science, Master's
Programme (N2COS) and 2) Computer Science, Bachelor's Programme (N1COS)
sections.Entry requirements:
The requirement for the course is to have successfully completed two years of studies
within the subject Computer Science or equivalent. The course DIT420 Computer
Communication is required.

Applicants must prove knowledge of English: English 6/English B or the equivalent level
of an internationally recognized test, for example TOEFL, IELTS.
sections.Learning outcomes:
1. Knowledge and understanding
After completion of the course the student is expected to be able to
- show knowledge about network design, administration, and traffic engineering.
- describe and analyze in detail the architecture, core protocols, global routing, services
and service limitations of the Internet.
- analyze and discuss contemporary networking problems such as IP mobility and
multimedia transmission over IP.

2. Skills and abilities
After completion of the course the student is expected to be able to:
- develop small scale network applications using fundamental networing techniquesand
and describe and justify these software developments.

3. Judgement and approach
- review Internet protocol specifications (RFCs) and their software implementation.
- point out cases in which the software inefficiently consumes the system resources.
sections.Course content:
This course, which builds on the fundamental TCP/IP courses, aims to provide in-depth
knowledge of the core technology, services, and applications used in computer networks
and the Internet. This course provides the students the ability to understand
fundamental issues in computer networks and would consider Internet technologies as
an example. Moreover, the course provides knowledge and skill to work in the area by
learning about important Internet protocols and concepts, such as:
Network equipment. Routing architecture and protocols. Switching. Multicast and
anycast. Mobile IP. Network design. Traffic engineering. Next generation Internet
protocols. Tools and methods for remote network administration. Analysis of core
services and protocols such as ICMP and DNS. Voice and video transmission over
Internet. Design of networks protocols. Lectures and laboratory assignments.
sections.Sub-courses:
The course is divided into the following sub-courses:
Written examination, 6,0 hp
Laboratory, 1,5 hp
sections.Assessment:
The course is examined by an individual written hall examination (U-VG) at the end of
the course and approved assignments (U-G). The assignments are carried out in pairs, if
possible.
A student who has failed the same examination twice has the right to request of the
department a change of examiner. The request is to be in writing and submitted as soon
as possible. The department is to grant such a request without undue delay. In cases
where a course has been discontinued or major changes have been made a student
should be guaranteed at least three examination occasions (including the ordinary
examination occasion) during a time of at least one year from the last time the course
was given.
sections.Grades:
The grading scale comprises: Pass with Distinction (VG), Pass (G) and Fail (U).
In order to be awarded Pass for a full course, the students must Pass both the exam and
the assignments. To be awarded Pass with Distinction for a full course, the Pass with
Distinction must be obtained in the written exam and the assignments must be
approved.
sections.Course evaluation:
The course is evaluated through meetings both during and after the course between
teachers and student representatives. Further, an anonymous questionnaire is used to
ensure written information. As far as possible, evaluations are to be completed
electronically. The outcome of the evaluations serves to improve the course by
indicating which parts could be added, improved, changed or removed.
